comments.commentBody: They love the story of the self-made man and "only in this country" but then fall into the trap that the benefits from this country for the self-made mand are from the government - student loans, government backed loans, infrastructure etc.
Um, Rich - the globe's been cooling the past 14 years.

This is a ridiculous reason. Wrestling is a competitive sport.
So competitive it rarely has repeats in the Olympics.
That is why there are no known names in the media.
But there are so many history makers in wrestling each year.
I am a wrestler with a dream to be an Olympic champion.
Unlike the other sports wrestling has nothing after college.
While those kids go to a professional team. Us wrestlers
Train for the Olympics. No matter how much power you say
Or think you have no right to take out a sport that helped create
The Olympics. A better solution I see is create a professional
Wrestling program around real wrestling.
Think!

Your and others' comments here are disgusting. Beach volleyball, gymnastics and men's diving are real sports and draw a lot more viewers than wrestling. Why should your sport enjoy special treatment? And was your spelling of gymnastics "gynastics" a slap at all gymnasts as feminized? If you watched men's gymnastics you'd see that the athletes are anything but feminine. Their huge muscles bulge and they accomplish the most amazing feats of strength, balance, timing and coordination. I hope the arrogant and offensive response of the wrestling community encourages the IOC to stick with their decision.
I wish. I love skateboarding.
Historical seniority has its privileges; but I agree with you that there is no reason to disrespect other sporting endeavors while stressing the importance of wrestling to the Olympics.

"basketball teams perform better when led by former top players."
The Bobcats must feel cheated.

Hi folks,

I recently discovered i am also sensitive to Gluten. After my mother travelled abroad i basically lived on bread and olive oil. Little did i know the bread was really irritating my gut. Long story short i think it may be the gluten or method of bread preparation.

In my native country whole wheat is a staple crop and i vividly remember as a child how it was prepared:

1) Buy grains from the local village - guaranteed pesticide free and locally grown
2) Wash the grains and let them dry in the sun for at least two - three days
3) Take the seeds to a local stone mill
4) Prepare the dough and let it stand for at least 24 hours before preparing it in a clay oven.

If anyone suffers from an accidental Gluten dose - which i do at times due to cross contamination i would recommend in the following order:

1) have a generous dose of pineapples
2) Follow up with an equally generous dose of dried coconuts (you can actually buy very good quality coconuts imported from Pakistan here in Queens). I do soak the coconuts for 10 mins in warm water to reduce the affects of the Sulphur preservative. Coconut chips are a so so substitute - but i find most chips including organic ones very dry and lacking the essential virgin oil.
3) Good quality water, try to avoid fluoride

This has always helped me get back to work the next day with the same level of energy. Otherwise whenever i would suffer a Gluten attack it would be lethargy, achy body and overall just plain old stress.

Exactly right! I agreed to prepare a class outside my main area of expertise, and it has been invigorating. I am an adjunct professor now after having taught for 40 years. Retirement is different, but not dull by a long shot.

The reading, the course design, the visuals and media accessories in the course have all required different focus styles and attention to the short and long term outcomes of the course. What a gift my employer provided.

When the time comes, and I can hear the hoofs trotting behind me, I will ante up the bucks, buy the hearing aid, and make sure I am catching as much of the conversation as possible. Unless my friends, colleagues, and family start speaking in tongues, I hope to fend off cognitive loss for as long as possible.

I wonder if any research has been done to determine the effects of unbalanced hearing loss, where one ear has much more loss than the other?  For example, with one ear totally deaf, all of the audio information you experience is going directly to one side or the other of your brain.  This in a brain where one side is more analytic and the other more creative.  Would someone deaf in one ear appreciate music, but have a very difficult time understanding speech?  Or vice versa?

Amen, I have blamed Jimi Hendrix on any number of occasions. My students laugh, as if that were the punch line rather than the cautionary tale given the acoustics and amplification of the music they bludgeon into their heads in closed containers (cars and other small spaces). I am wondering what their hearing lives will be like at 40.

My friend David Green has done just that in India -- he got a well deserved MacArthur genius grant for his social entrepreneurship -- but it still needs to be done for the rest of the world.

Here's a document about the organization:www.globalgiving.org/pfil/936/projdoc.doc

I remember him saying that the cost of making them is pretty insignificant but the Western companies just charge what they can get!

My sister got hearing aids at Costco, and after she had them for a while (maybe about a year), Costco called and said she should come in for the new models--they were replacing them for FREE.!  This was just a few months ago.

I remember a friend of the family dropped her aids when she got out of the car at a car wash...and they got crushed. She cried and cried because the hearing aids were worth thousands of dollars.

I would imagine that only so much of the cost of the aids is in the manufacturing of them versus the actual technology and materials. So why couldn't hearing aids come with a guarantee of replacement (perhaps along with the payment of a small deductible)?

I would like to learn more about the technology behind hearing aids. How is it possible that they cost as much as they do???

There simply MUST be a way to get the cost of hearing aids down.

It's a business opportunity in the making. Product designers have managed to create low cost laptops for use by children in poor African communities as well as low cost wheelchairs and eyeglasses.

What about hearing aids???

After wearing hearing aids for a while I began to notice that some of my friends needed help: they "lean in" when I talk to them. I began to realize the meaning of the sign on the wall of my audiologist's office:
"A hearing problem is more obvious than a hearing aid"

For the first time since the 1990's I did not watch the state of the union address. I find the president cannot deviate from campaign style speeches and rhetoric. The FactCheck folks showed that virtually all he said stretched the truth.

The fact that the public believes the country is heading in the wrong direction, yet can re-elect the president, speaks to the politics of divde and conquer that the president does so well. While he detests the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq he creates the "wars" on women, poor, unions, immigrants, etc., etc. The money he raises and spends on his campaigns is obscene. He constantly blamed Bush in his first three years, and now uses a more generic "rich" or republicans. Compromise in his dictionary means capituate to my will.

The country got it right in 2010 - it defeated a number of democrats in the house and not enough democrats in the senate, but turned the tide on the run away power grab lead by the 3-headed hydra of Obama, Reid and Pelosi.

Sadly, we have four more years of this presidency. the republican party must take this time to craft a consistent message and get it out in spite of the tepid coverage granted in the press.

One day we will learn the truth about the Benghazi attack and "Fast and Furious". The most transparent administration can stonewall with the best of them but in the end the truth will come out. It will take reporters with more backbone than a Steve Croft to bring the truth to light.
He's criticized for too much emotion or not enough emotion. I'm so glad he's made of much thicker skin than me.

To Mike W:
Re FactCheck-ing -- if you thought they found a lot to chew on in the SOTU, check out their little Valentine to the 'replies' on their site. But I'm thinking that holds little interest for someone in your state of mind.

And as far as getting to the bottom of Benghazi and the four US deaths there, I'd like to get to the bottom of the four thousand US deaths in Iraq. Let us know when that happens--

Therein lies the Obama likabilty, of many Americans...The emotional moments when he becomes the preacher of right and wrong. It happened in his State of the Union speech, starting with new gun control laws, naming the victims of the recent atrocities, building up to a crescendo that had all of Congress on their feet applauding.

It was the right thing to do, but the emotional rise of voice by the president, at the name of each victim that had Congress on their feet, is what it is...an emotional moment...a fleeting moment to be forgotten in their evening cocktail parties.

A more serious and sobering version, using the same words and names of the victims by our president, would surely have left a longer and deeper impression on those in Congress.

It is the Obama key to his likabilty...the passion of a preacher at the moment...only to be lost when facing the reality of working with others to achieve what must be done.

Politics at its best.
That is a sad story. Good luck to you....to both of you.  I hope his infatuation fades and you get your life back.

Yes, I agree with you. It's not suitable for everyone and once the excitement dissipates, my interest dissipates as well. That's not to say I wouldn't still love the man in a more compassionate manner but I like the attraction of other men.
You've hit the nail on the head, Sheri. It's always been my sense that I don't need a man or children to validate my existence.

Our left frontal lobe is associated with positive emotions, and our right negative. Depression could be a case of an underactive left frontal lobe and an overactive right. Thus, damage to the left hemisphere in patients results in a marked increase in depression. (see Lane, R.D., and L. Nadel)
Do you know the web address of the manufacturer?  Googling only results in a list of merchants.  Thanks.

I used to take a variety of antidepressants for 15+ years, experienced many side effects and little relief. I hope anyone reading this article will also see the NYT article 'Light Therapy for Depression'. Light therapy has helped me more than I could ever have imagined. After several weeks of it, I was able to discontinue antidepressants entirely...no exaggeration. I use the Philips GoLite Blu device, and I should mention that it's important for those interested in it to take the assessment test on the manufacturer's website before beginning so they can get the maximum benefit for their needs. I bought mine at Costco so I could return it at any time in case it didn't work for me.

The device is also capable of resetting circadian rhythm (i.e., convert a night owl to an early bird).
I don't  get it? Why not just enjoy fresh fruit , vegetables  and whole grains? Forget the ersatz substitutes and enjoy what is real.

I was a little disappointed to see that most of the recommended resources given at the end of the article were for 12-step programs. One 12-step precept has been: "Giving up drugs, for an addict, is always an act of surrender."

Not so. It can often be a supreme act of triumph. I stopped death-spiral drinking 12 years ago, and I did it without "surrender."

The "I am powerless, I surrender" ploy is what the 12-step programs use. I realize that for some people, AA is a great way to stop drinking. For many I know, the addiction to booze has been replaced by an addiction to AA meetings. (I have attended over 100 AA meetings, so I do not reject the 12-step model from ignorance.)

I would go nuts (and maybe start drinking) if I dwelled on liquor in my daily thoughts or at endless AA meetings, where all they ever talk about is drinking, drinking, drinking. As an atheist, I completely reject the "higher power" hooey. AA is an outgrowth of that same scary Buchmanism that gave us Moral Rearmament; Nan Robertson is good to read on the subject.

I was lucky to have a health plan that allowed me daily (7 days a week) outpatient cognitive behavior therapy: group meetings, education, individual therapy, for six months. They accepted my rejection of the 12-step model. Now I really don't give much attention at all to drink, and I like that freedom, both from drinking and from endless meetings.

Actually John....I believe that harsh criticism makes it more difficult to learn because the recipient of the criticism is probably in a state of shock, shame and embarrassment and unable to attend to what the "teacher" is telling him. A question and answer session, done in a calm manner, would seem to be the better way because it forces the malefactor to actually think about his actions and think about how to avoid mistakes in the future.
What fraction of the meds/herbs/pastes/essences that you prescribe are regulated by the FDA?

I know this isn't the point of the article, BUT... 100,000 deaths a year from medical errors??? Could we all just stop and contemplate that for a minute? I am a CAM practitioner, a naturopathic physician.I went to an accredited 4 year post graduate institution to learn science based natural medicine. Emphasis on science based, for all those who want to claim there's no scientific backing for natural medicine. I have a license granted by a state board that allows me to practice natural medicine.

If my profession killed even a fraction of that number of patients, we'd all be put in jail and every herb, acupuncture needle, and homeopathic remedy would be outlawed.

The habit of referring to internet and self diagnosis ans self medication is on the rise.

This is a dangerous practice.

On the other hand , not all the information on the Internet, that is featured in the first search results are correct.

People have a tendency to follow the top results.

But entering into a subject which is a matter of Life and Death, it is inadvisable and dangerous.

As things stand to-day the concept of family Doctor, who knows your Family History(not merely Health) who knows the patient well, who examines you physically, allows you to talk freely of your symptoms and order you to follow his advice is gone.

We have assembly line Medicare, where the Doctors have to refer to files even for Names and at tames the Hospital where they had seen the a patient!

Personal care is gone.

It is alright for the Doctor to discuss the case with you.

Because you have access to Internet, you do not become a Doctor.

Don’t do this, for health’s sake.
If insurance companies would compensate doctors for more than just 15 measly minutes to evaluate patients, they wouldn't have this problem.
